Working of SVM:🔗

  1. Linearly Separable Data:

    • In a two-dimensional space, this hyperplane is a line dividing a plane in two parts wherein each class lays on either side.
    • For higher dimensions, it's called a hyperplane.

  2. Optimal Hyperplane:

    • SVMs select the hyperplane which separates the classes best by maximizing the margin between two data classes.
    • The vectors (or data points) that define this maximum margin are called support vectors.

  3. Non-linearly Separable Data:

    • In real-world scenarios, data is often not linearly separable.
    • SVMs handle this by using a trick called the kernel trick. The kernel trick involves transforming the input space into a higher-dimensional space where the data becomes linearly separable.

SVM Loss Function:🔗

The objective of the SVM is two-fold:

  1. Maximize the margin (distance between the hyperplane and the nearest data point from either class).
  2. Minimize classification errors.

The total SVM loss function (also known as the hinge loss) combines these two objectives.

Given:

  • www is the weight vector.
  • bbb is the bias.
  • ξ\xiξ (xi) are the slack variables that measure the degree of misclassification of the data point xix_ixi​.

The SVM optimization problem can be written as:

min⁡w,b,ξ12∣∣w∣∣2+C∑iξi\min_{w,b,\xi} \frac{1}{2} ||w||^2 + C \sum_i \xi_iw,b,ξmin​21​∣∣w∣∣2+Ci∑​ξi​

Subject to:

yi(w⋅xi+b)≥1−ξiandξi≥0y_i(w \cdot x_i + b) \geq 1 - \xi_i \quad \text{and} \quad \xi_i \geq 0yi​(w⋅xi​+b)≥1−ξi​andξi​≥0

Here:

  • 12∣∣w∣∣2\frac{1}{2} ||w||^221​∣∣w∣∣2 is the margin term. Minimizing ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣ maximizes the margin.
  • ξi\xi_iξi​ are slack variables introduced to allow some misclassifications or points to fall within the margin. This is necessary for non-linearly separable data.
  • CCC is a regularization parameter. It determines the trade-off between maximizing the margin and minimizing classification error. A large CCC places more emphasis on minimizing misclassification.

In simpler terms, SVM tries to find a balance between maximizing the margin and minimizing the misclassification. The exact balance is controlled by the parameter CCC.

How minimizing ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣ maximizes the margin?🔗

The decision boundary or hyperplane in SVM is defined by:

w⋅x+b=0w \cdot x + b = 0w⋅x+b=0

Where:

  • www is the weight vector.

For any data point on the positive margin (support vector of the positive class), the equation is:

w⋅x++b=1w \cdot x_{+} + b = 1w⋅x+​+b=1

For any data point on the negative margin (support vector of the negative class), the equation is:

w⋅x−+b=−1w \cdot x_{-} + b = -1w⋅x−​+b=−1

To find the distance between these two hyperplanes (which is the margin), subtract the two equations:

w⋅(x+−x−)=2w \cdot (x_{+} - x_{-}) = 2w⋅(x+​−x−​)=2

The margin, margin\text{margin}margin, is the distance between these two hyperplanes and is given by:

From the above equation, you can see that the margin is inversely proportional to ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣. So, minimizing ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣ will maximize the margin.

Example:🔗

Imagine you're trying to separate two classes using a stick (the hyperplane). The length of the stick is like 1/∣∣w∣∣1/||w||1/∣∣w∣∣. The longer the stick, the bigger the gap (margin) you can create between the two classes. By trying to get the longest stick (minimizing ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣), you're ensuring the largest gap or margin.

Slack Variables:🔗

In many real-world scenarios, the data is not perfectly linearly separable. This means you can't always find a hyperplane that will perfectly separate the classes without any errors. Here's where slack variables, ξ\xiξ, come in.

For each data point, a corresponding slack variable ξi\xi_iξi​ is introduced:

  • ξi=0\xi_i = 0ξi​=0: The data point is on the correct side, outside the margin.
  • 0<ξi<10 < \xi_i < 10<ξi​<1: The data point is on the correct side but inside the margin.
  • ξi≥1\xi_i \geq 1ξi​≥1: The data point is on the wrong side of the hyperplane.

By introducing these slack variables, SVM allows some misclassifications, ensuring the algorithm can find a solution even if the data is not perfectly linearly separable.

Example:🔗

Imagine you're trying to separate cats and dogs based on weight and height. While most of the data is separable, there's one unusually large cat that sits amidst the dogs.

Without slack variables, you might struggle to find a separating line because of this one outlier. However, by introducing a slack variable for this cat, you allow it to be misclassified (or be within the margin) and focus on getting a hyperplane that works well for the majority of the data.

In essence, slack variables provide SVM with the flexibility to handle real-world, imperfect data. They permit certain violations of the margin and even the hyperplane for the sake of achieving a more generalized and robust model.

Slack variables (ξ\xiξ) in SVM are introduced to handle non-linearly separable data, allowing some data points to be misclassified or to lie within the margin. They provide flexibility in finding the optimal hyperplane.

Calculating Slack Variables:🔗

For each data point xix_ixi​, the corresponding slack variable ξi\xi_iξi​ is defined based on the position of the data point relative to the hyperplane and the margin:

  1. If xix_ixi​ is correctly classified and lies outside the margin: ξi=0\xi_i = 0ξi​=0

  2. If xix_ixi​ is correctly classified but lies inside the margin: 0<ξi<10 < \xi_i < 10<ξi​<1

  3. If xix_ixi​ is misclassified: ξi≥1\xi_i \geq 1ξi​≥1

Mathematically, the constraints involving the slack variables for each data point xix_ixi​ can be written as:

yi(w⋅xi+b)≥1−ξiy_i (w \cdot x_i + b) \geq 1 - \xi_i yi​(w⋅xi​+b)≥1−ξi​

Where:

  • yiy_iyi​ is the true label of xix_ixi​ (either +1 or -1).
  • www is the weight vector.
  • bbb is the bias.

The value of ξi\xi_iξi​ for each data point is determined during the optimization process of the SVM. It's a result of the trade-off between maximizing the margin and minimizing the classification error, controlled by the regularization parameter CCC.

Choosing Value for CCC:🔗

The parameter CCC in SVM determines the trade-off between maximizing the margin and minimizing the classification error (misclassifications). Specifically, CCC sets the penalty for misclassification:

  • A large value of CCC:

    • Places a high penalty on misclassification.
    • Results in a smaller margin if that's what's required to classify more points correctly.
    • Might overfit to the training data.

  • A small value of CCC:

    • Allows some misclassifications in favor of a wider margin.
    • Might provide a more generalized solution.

The best value for CCC is typically chosen using cross-validation. You'd train the SVM with multiple values of CCC on your training data and select the value that performs best on a validation set. This ensures that the model generalizes well to unseen data.

The Role of CCC in SVM:🔗

The parameter CCC in SVM is a regularization parameter that determines the trade-off between achieving a wide margin and ensuring that the data points are correctly classified.

  • High CCC: Emphasizes the importance of classifying all the training examples correctly. Even if it means choosing a smaller margin. If CCC is very high, the SVM will try its best not to misclassify any data points, even at the risk of overfitting.

  • Low CCC: Emphasizes the importance of a wide margin. Even if it means allowing some misclassifications in the training data. If CCC is very low, the SVM will prioritize a wider margin, even if it misclassifies some points.

Analogy:🔗

Imagine you're a teacher trying to draw a line in a playground to separate two groups of students: younger students and older students. The line represents the decision boundary.

  • If you're very strict (high CCC), you'll want to ensure that every single student is on the correct side of the line, even if the line is somewhat crooked or very close to some students (small margin).

  • If you're more lenient (low CCC), you'll focus on drawing a straight line that generally separates the two groups, even if a few younger students end up on the older students' side and vice versa. The primary concern here is to keep as much space (margin) between the line and most students.

Detailed Example:🔗

Consider two classes of data points on a 2D plane. Most of the points are linearly separable, but there are a few outliers.

  1. High CCC:

    • The SVM will try its best to classify every point correctly.
    • It might draw a zigzagged line to ensure the outliers are also correctly classified.
    • This might result in a smaller margin (the distance between the line and the nearest points).
    • The model could perform poorly on new data because it's too focused on the training data (overfitting).

  2. Low CCC:

    • The SVM will allow some misclassifications, especially if they are outliers.
    • It will draw a straight line that best separates the two classes, ignoring a few misclassifications.
    • This results in a wider margin.
    • The model might generalize better to new data because it's not overly influenced by the noise or outliers in the training data.

In practical machine learning workflows, you would use techniques like cross-validation to experiment with different values of CCC and find the one that gives the best performance on unseen data. The goal is to strike a balance between classifying training data correctly and ensuring the model generalizes well to new data.
